title: Aegean obsidian from Melos and Yali is found in western Anatolia
Anatolian copper and tin found their way into the Aegean (Gale 2008), and trade in these most precious Bronze Age commodities is likely to have been of central importance

Exchange was not only in raw materials but also in behaviors. Cycladic figurines are reported from Cnidus (Bent 1888, 82) and from Miletus, a site that has also yielded six Anatolian-type figurines (W.-D

These may represent direct east-west trade, prestige goods radiating out from the islands, or ritual activity (Broodbank 2000, 308; Niemeier 2005, 2). There is also evidence of the adoption of Anatolian drinking behaviors at EH
Two models for understanding EBA trade networks have been proposed: Vasif Şahoğlu’s maritime ‘Anatolian Trade Network

crossing Anatolia from Cilicia to the Troad but essentially bypassing southwest Anatolia and the Aegean altogether. These models provide a useful basis for future discussion and impetus for further survey, excavation, and scientific analysis
